introduction.title: The Path to Implementation
introduction.paragraph1: So after I had grasped the basic idea – Spain could really become my new home – and the advantages I saw in it outweighed my initial fears, it was time to make a real plan. The dream alone is not enough. I wanted to understand: Is this whole thing even feasible? What requirements do I have to meet? And what could a realistic timeline look like?
introduction.paragraph2: Fortunately, the internet is full of information – and of course, I'm not the first German to consider emigrating to Spain. A real constant companion of my research became Idealista. For those who don't know: Idealista is not only the largest real estate platform in Spain (comparable to Immoscout24 in Germany), but also a real treasure trove of information.
introduction.paragraph3: Right at the beginning, four main topics crystallized for me:

intro.title: The Most Important Thing First
intro.question: Can I as a German really live in Spain so easily?
intro.answer: The short answer: Yes. As an EU citizen, I have the right to settle, live and work in any EU member state – without any visa or residence permit. This right is called freedom of movement and is regulated in EU regulations.
intro.note: Sounds easy at first. But in practice there are naturally details:

registration.title: Registration Requirement from 3 Months
registration.point1: Anyone staying longer than 3 months must register with the immigration office (Extranjería)
registration.point2: You receive the so-called "Certificado de registro como residente comunitario"
registration.point3: For this you need income, employment contract or proof of sufficient financial means

taxRule.title: The 183-Day Rule
taxRule.conclusion: From 183 days onwards, tax residency in Spain applies.

work.title: Work
work.intro: Of course, work was a central topic for me. After all, like most people, I depend on my income. My research quickly showed me: In principle, there are two options for me.

remote.title: Option 1: Remote Work from Germany
remote.point2: Security because you stay with the German employer
remote.point3: Social security system remains the same
remote.point4: Flexibility: you can travel without immediately changing all systems in Spain
remote.warning: 183-day rule → as soon as I stay too long in Spain, it becomes tax complicated

spain.title: Option 2: Working directly in Spain
spain.disadvantage: Salaries in Spain are on average significantly lower than German ones. 2025: Spain ~28,000€ vs. Germany ~46,000€

decision.title: Remote Work as a Transition Solution
decision.description: As a transition, I'm starting with remote work. This helped me immensely – I could arrange everything on site (bank account, Gestoría, apartment, etc.) without having to take vacation each time. And yes, it saved me a lot of money for flights.
decision.reminder: Anyone working remotely from Spain should keep an eye on the 183-day rule

taxes.title: Taxes & Salary Calculation
taxes.intro: Taxes were the next big topic – after all, you don't want to fall into a trap. Here I show you a detailed salary calculation for €2,500 gross comparing Germany vs. Spain.

summary.title: Summary
summary.conclusion: With €2,500 gross, about 15% more net remains in Spain than in Germany. Deductions are significantly higher in Germany (36.8% vs. 27.1% of gross).
summary.importantNote: In Spain, it is significantly more difficult to achieve a salary of €2,500 gross. The average salary is around €1,800 gross, while in Germany it's around €3,200.
summary.disclaimer: This calculation is an example. Actual deductions depend on many factors. Consultation with a tax advisor is recommended.

livingCosts.title: Cost of Living
livingCosts.intro: Everyone who goes on vacation in Spain says at first: "Wow, everything here is so cheap!" But that's only half the truth. Yes, a tapa for €2.50 and a café con leche for €1.20 seem ridiculously cheap to us Germans. But the feeling arises mainly because we have German salaries in mind.

energy.title: Energy
energy.disclaimer: This is a purely calculated example for an average 2-person household. Actual costs can vary greatly depending on consumption behavior, provider, region and season. In Spain, costs can be further reduced by optimal use of night-time electricity rates.

europeanComparison.title: European Comparison
europeanComparison.conclusionText: Spain's cost of living is about 20-30% below German levels and positions itself in the middle range of Europe

intro.title: An Unexpected Advantage
intro.description: As someone with celiac disease, this was a real game-changer for me. I hadn't expected Spain to be so much better equipped in this area than Germany.

positiveSurprise.title: Positive Surprise in Spain
positiveSurprise.description1: In Spain, I was honestly positively surprised. Even during my first stays, I noticed that awareness of gluten-free nutrition ("sin gluten") is much more pronounced here. Almost every larger supermarket has entire shelves with gluten-free products.
positiveSurprise.description2: Even when eating out, it often looks more relaxed in Spain. Many restaurants and cafés clearly mark their menus with "sin gluten" symbols, and there are chains like 100 Montaditos or VIPS that explicitly offer gluten-free options.

supermarkets.title: Supermarket chains with large gluten-free selection:
supermarkets.mercadona: Mercadona – probably the best first point of contact
supermarkets.carrefour: Carrefour – wide selection of brand products
supermarkets.alcampo: Alcampo – large hypermarkets with good coverage
supermarkets.lidl: Lidl Spain – some gluten-free own-brand products

conclusion.title: My Conclusion
conclusion.description: Spain is a really good country for people with celiac disease. The combination of large product selection in supermarkets, diverse natural cuisine, and growing awareness in gastronomy makes everyday life here much easier for me.

conclusion.title: Conclusion of My Research
conclusion.intro: At the end of my research, I was wiser – and honestly more motivated too. I knew:

residenceRights.title: ✅ Residence Rights
residenceRights.description: As a German, relatively uncomplicated, but with obligations from 3 months or 183 days respectively.

work.title: ✅ Work
work.description: Remote from Germany = financially more attractive, but with tax pitfalls.

taxes.title: ✅ Taxes
taxes.description: Complex, regionally different, you need good advice.

livingCosts.title: ✅ Cost of Living
livingCosts.description: At first glance cheap, but realistically only in relation to Spanish salaries.

bonus.title: Bonus: Gluten-Free Food
bonus.description: Obviously easier and more varied than in Germany, both in supermarkets and restaurants.
